answer_html: Thus, as \(\displaystyle p-1\) is even, we have that \(\displaystyle \alpha = 1\) (or n is odd) and further that \(\displaystyle p = 15\) which is not a prime.This is a contradiction and hence this equation has no solution.
answer_latex:
Thus, as $\displaystyle p-1$ is even, we have that
$\displaystyle \alpha = 1$ (or \emph{n} is odd) and further that
$\displaystyle p = 15$ which is not a prime.This is a contradiction and
hence this equation has no solution.
hints_html:
For the last part, use the fact that

\(\displaystyle \phi(n) = n \prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n}p^{\alpha-1}(p-1) = 14\).

where \(\displaystyle n = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n} p^{\alpha}\) and where we recall that \(\displaystyle p^{\alpha} \parallel n\) means that \(\displaystyle p^{\alpha}\) fully divides n (that is, this is the highest power of p that divides n).
hints_latex:
For the last part, use the fact that

$\displaystyle \phi(n) = n \prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n}p^{\alpha-1}(p-1) = 14$.

where $\displaystyle n = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n} p^{\alpha}$ and
where we recall that $\displaystyle p^{\alpha} \parallel n$ means that
$\displaystyle p^{\alpha}$ fully divides \emph{n} (that is, this is the
highest power of \emph{p} that divides \emph{n}).
hints_raw:
For the last part, use the fact that 

<math> \displaystyle \phi(n) = n \prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n}p^{\alpha-1}(p-1) = 14</math>.

where <math> \displaystyle n = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n} p^{\alpha}</math> and where we recall that <math> \displaystyle p^{\alpha} \parallel n </math> means that <math> \displaystyle p^{\alpha} </math> fully divides ''n'' (that is, this is the highest power of ''p'' that divides ''n'').
sols_html:
First,

\(\displaystyle \sigma(n) = \sum_{d \mid n} d\)

and

\(\displaystyle \tau(n) = \sum_{d \mid n}1\)

gives the required definitions.

For the last part, we proceed by a contradiction and suppose that \(\displaystyle \phi(n) = 14\) for some integer n.

As stated in the hint, we have

\(\displaystyle \phi(n) = n \prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n}p^{\alpha_{p}-1}(p-1) = 14\).

where \(\displaystyle n = \prod p^{\alpha_{p}}\). Now every odd prime present in the factorization of n contributes a power of two to \(\displaystyle \phi(n)\) due to the \(\displaystyle (p-1)\) factor. Thus, there can be at most one odd prime dividing n, say \(\displaystyle p\).

If \(\displaystyle p\) occurs to a power of two, then because it divides the left hand side, it must divide 14 and so must be 7. The prime \(\displaystyle p\) cannot occur to a third power or higher since otherwise there are two factors of \(\displaystyle p\) on the left and at most one on the right. However \(\displaystyle \phi(7^{2}) = 42 > 14\) and so the power must be 1. Thus \(\displaystyle n = 2^{\alpha} p\) for some \(\displaystyle \alpha\). Notice that as the phi-function is multiplicative, we have that

\(\displaystyle 14 = \phi(n) = \phi(2^{\alpha})\phi(p) = 2^{\alpha-1}(p-1)\)

(or we have that \(\displaystyle \phi(n) = p-1\) if no power of 2 divides n)

Thus, as \(\displaystyle p-1\) is even, we have that \(\displaystyle \alpha = 1\) (or n is odd) and further that \(\displaystyle p = 15\) which is not a prime. This is a contradiction and hence this equation has no solution.

First,

$\displaystyle \sigma(n) = \sum_{d \mid n} d$

and

$\displaystyle \tau(n) = \sum_{d \mid n}1$

gives the required definitions.

For the last part, we proceed by a contradiction and suppose that
$\displaystyle \phi(n) = 14$ for some integer \emph{n}.

As stated in the hint, we have

$\displaystyle \phi(n) = n \prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n}p^{\alpha_{p}-1}(p-1) = 14$.

where $\displaystyle n = \prod p^{\alpha_{p}}$. Now every odd prime
present in the factorization of \emph{n} contributes a power of two to
$\displaystyle \phi(n)$ due to the $\displaystyle (p-1)$ factor. Thus,
there can be at most one odd prime dividing \emph{n}, say
$\displaystyle p$.

If $\displaystyle p$ occurs to a power of two, then because it divides
the left hand side, it must divide 14 and so must be 7. The prime
$\displaystyle p$ cannot occur to a third power or higher since
otherwise there are two factors of $\displaystyle p$ on the left and at
most one on the right. However $\displaystyle \phi(7^{2}) = 42 > 14$ and
so the power must be 1. Thus $\displaystyle n = 2^{\alpha} p$ for some
$\displaystyle \alpha$. Notice that as the phi-function is
multiplicative, we have that

$\displaystyle 14 = \phi(n) = \phi(2^{\alpha})\phi(p) = 2^{\alpha-1}(p-1)$

(or we have that $\displaystyle \phi(n) = p-1$ if no power of 2 divides
n)

Thus, as $\displaystyle p-1$ is even, we have that
$\displaystyle \alpha = 1$ (or \emph{n} is odd) and further that
$\displaystyle p = 15$ which is not a prime. This is a contradiction and
hence this equation has no solution.
sols_raw:
First,

<math> \displaystyle \sigma(n) = \sum_{d \mid n} d</math>

and

<math> \displaystyle \tau(n) = \sum_{d \mid n}1</math>

gives the required definitions. 

For the last part, we proceed by a contradiction and suppose that <math> \displaystyle \phi(n) = 14</math> for some integer ''n''.

As stated in the hint, we have

<math> \displaystyle \phi(n) = n \prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = \prod_{p^{\alpha} \parallel n}p^{\alpha_{p}-1}(p-1) = 14</math>.

where <math> \displaystyle n = \prod p^{\alpha_{p}}</math>. Now every odd prime present in the factorization of ''n'' contributes a power of two to <math> \displaystyle \phi(n)</math> due to the <math> \displaystyle (p-1) </math> factor. Thus, there can be at most one odd prime dividing ''n'', say <math> \displaystyle p </math>.

If <math> \displaystyle p </math> occurs to a power of two, then because it divides the left hand side, it must divide 14 and so must be 7. The prime <math> \displaystyle p </math> cannot occur to a third power or higher since otherwise there are two factors of <math> \displaystyle p </math> on the left and at most one on the right. However <math> \displaystyle \phi(7^{2}) = 42 > 14</math> and so the power must be 1. Thus <math> \displaystyle n = 2^{\alpha} p</math> for some <math> \displaystyle \alpha</math>. Notice that as the phi-function is multiplicative, we have that 

<math> \displaystyle 14 = \phi(n) = \phi(2^{\alpha})\phi(p) = 2^{\alpha-1}(p-1)</math>

(or we have that <math> \displaystyle \phi(n) = p-1</math> if no power of 2 divides n)

Thus, as <math> \displaystyle p-1</math> is even, we have that <math> \displaystyle \alpha = 1</math> (or ''n'' is odd) and further that <math> \displaystyle p = 15</math> which is not a prime. This is a contradiction and hence this equation has no solution.
statement_html: Define the sum of divisors function \(\displaystyle \sigma(n)\) and number of divisors function \(\displaystyle \tau(n)\). Show that there is no positive integer n with \(\displaystyle \phi(n) = 14.\)
statement_latex:
Define the sum of divisors function $\displaystyle \sigma(n)$ and number
of divisors function $\displaystyle \tau(n)$. Show that there is no
positive integer \emph{n} with $\displaystyle \phi(n) = 14.$
statement_raw: Define the sum of divisors function <math>\displaystyle \sigma(n) </math> and number of divisors function <math> \displaystyle \tau(n) </math>. Show that there is no positive integer ''n'' with <math> \displaystyle \phi(n) = 14. </math>
